results.title: Savage indictment (A)
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Adler, Caroline Sherwood, Channel Four Television and Titus Films
results.brief_description: A look at Australia in the 1960’s through a court case against James Savage, an Aborigine, who was on trial in the United States for murder. Gives an account of the government policy which removed half-caste Aboriginal children from their natural parents and placed them with white families. Includes interviews with some of those children who are now grown up. Savage was sentenced to death in January 1990, a sentence subsequently commuted to life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicholas Adler, Caroline Sherwood, Channel Four Television and Titus Films

results.title: Last chance for the lucky country
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Geoffrey Barnes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The six programs use archival material, case studies of products and people and comparisons with other nations to show how Australia has fallen behind other nations through not utilizing its intellectual and enterpreneurial talent. The programs are: “Cringe dwellers” tells how some of our world firsts were stolen by more resourceful countries. “The Backward frontiers” looks at rural innovations. “Desperately seeking solutions” compares our research and development with Japan and U.S.A. “Ordinary people, extraordinary ideas” looks at the future of innovation. “Inventing the future” a view of the new breed of entrepreneurs. “Up the J curve” the story of our industrial decay, pointing to the light at the end of the tunnel. Accompanied by one teacher’s guide and student activities.

results.title: Australian trains and tracks
results.brief_description: Jim Downes presents this program which explores the diversity of Australian tracks and trains in the great era of rail transport following World War Two.

results.title: The Story of the Olympics
results.creator_credit: Derek Conrad and Conrad Television Associates
results.brief_description: This video will delight anyone with a love of sport or a general interest in the history of one of the world’s greatest sporting events. From as early as the first Olympic marathon which was won, appropriately enough by a Greek water-carrier, to as recent as the Seoul 1988, when the return of the Russians pushed the United States into third place and the drugs issue made headlines a Ben Johnson was stripped of his medal, you can relive the triumph and the heartache that have combined to make the Olympics the inspiration that they are today.

results.title: A Brief history of time
results.creator_credit: Errol Morris, David Hickman, Gordon Freedman and Anglia Television
results.brief_description: A biography of brilliant physicist Professor Stephen Hawking who has expanded and re-evaluated our knowledge of science despite having ALS - Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis since the age of 21. An inspirational film exploring the infinite possibilities of the human mind in extending the boundaries of knowledge in regard to why we and the universe exist. The bold use of graphics and striking imagery address theories surrounding an expanding universe, the creation, black holes and past, present and future.

results.title: Last man hanged
results.brief_description: This dramatised documentary depicts the events leading up to the hanging of Ronald Ryan in Pentridge Gaol in 1967 - the last man hanged in Australia. Through the eyes of Keith Willey (Lewis Fitz-Gerald), the journalist who followed the case, we see Ryan as a complex man who was as much a victim as those he had violated. This documentary details how the State Premier, Sir Henry Bolte, facing an imminent election, decided to make an issue of the case and pushed through the hanging despite nationwide protest. What evolves is powerful and emotional statement about capital punishment.

results.title: Teachers of the world. Part 2
results.brief_description: Globalisation of information, new technologies, the changing nature of our lives, are factors forcing educators everywhere to face an unprecedented period of reassessment. The teachers in this video are meeting this challenge head-on. “Korea” : a teacher uses drawings and cartoons to teach geometry. “United States of America” : an history teacher creates an experimental learning situation to foster an understanding of social injustice in her students. “Poland” : a teacher has his students exploring tradition and cultural taboo in relation to change and compromise.

results.title: Teachers of the world. Part 1
results.brief_description: Globalisation of information, new technologies, the changing nature of our lives and our work, are factors forcing educators everywhere to face an unprecedented period of reassessment. The teachers in this video are meeting the challenge head-on. “Australia”: Stephanie Lawrence, a teacher from Devonport, Tasmania, uses self actualisation techniques to develop her students self-esteem. “Japan”: Shigeto Honda, a teacher from Ichikawa City near Tokyo, teaches his students about the diversities of Asian cultures by experiencing first hand. “Canada and Finland”: Pekka Hynninen from Rantasalmi in rural Finland takes his students on a hike and boat trip for a scientific environmental study. The class of Rachel Hunneault from Northern Ontario participates in an interactive Telecommunications Network.

results.title: A Kid called Troy
results.creator_credit: Terry Carlyon, Michael J. Rivette and Carlyon and Rivette Pictures
results.brief_description: A profoundly moving and inspirational sequel to the critically acclaimed “Suzi’s Story”. It is the story of Vince and Troy Lovegrove, the father and son who survived Suzi when she died from AIDS in 1987. Troy carried the AIDS virus from birth. This is Troy’s story - the story of what it is to be seven, to love life as only a child can and yet to be a victim of AIDS.

results.title: Forbidden love: the unashamed stories of lesbian lives
results.creator_credit: Lynne Fernie, Aerlyn Weissman, Ginny Stikeman, Margaret Pettigrew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Against a backdrop of bookcovers from lurid lesbian pulp novels, “Forbidden Love” paints a compelling and often hilarious portrait of lesbian sexuality and survival in Canada in the 1950’s and 60’s when lesbian love was consigned to the twilight world of silence and exile. Ten women tell their own stories of first loves and life in the clandestine subculture with the candour of true survivors. Due to the explicit nature of certain scenes, viewer discretion is advised.
